content.paragraph: I'm Martin Ritsberg, a student at the Tartu Vocational College and an aspiring software developer. I began my journey in software development after about 10 years of experience in IT support, including acting as a client representative in software development contracts and dabbling in writing some utilitarian scripts for in-house use. When I got the opportunity to challenge myself with the opportunity to become a software developer, it seemed like a no-brainer. I love problem solving and helping others. So the way software developers define problems, solve issues and implement technical solutions is very near to my character.

content.header2: See my CV with my contact info here.

content.paragraph: During my youth I was fascinated by technology, I especially liked to tinker with computers. Trying to see what made them tick, both on the software and the hardware side. This passion led me to start a career in IT.

content.header3: 2024 - Began my studies in Software Development at Tartu Vocational College

content.paragraph: Studies so far have taught me web development and the fundamentals of software development. This includes technologies such as HTML5, React, Node.js and SQL, as well as abilities at documenting and planning software development projects.

content.header3: 10 years as IT Specialist and Project Manager

content.paragraph: Including the usual duties of managing the firm's IT infrastructure and offering internal IT support, I was also deeply involved in various IT related projects. This included software development contracts, where I was responsible for compiling requirements from the client side and helped find technical solutions. I also wrote VBA scripts to automate document generation and help bookkeeping.

I feel proficient in HTML, CSS and JavaScript. I know how to create a semantic HTML structure and replicate most designs in CSS. In JavaScript I can handle more complex subjects such as asynchronous functions and object oriented programming. I also know how to create websites with WordPress and know how to do some advanced customization with it, like editing themes.
I know how to use React to build web applications and am also learning additional technologies like Next.js and React Native. I'm also curious about WebAssembly.

For the backend, I've learned to use Node.js and PHP, with the focus on Node.js. I know how to create API endpoints, create database connections and serve web pages from templates. The backend is the aspect of programming I'm most interested in and am looking forward to further expanding my skills in.

I know how to use SQL databases like MySQL and MariaDB, including some more advanced features like creating procedures and views. I also know the fundamentals of using MongoDB and how to model database structures.

I know how to read and write basic project documentation. I've been taught topics like how to write software requirements and use cases, how to account for the clients business model in software development and track the progress of projects.
I know the basics of how to create GitHub pull requests and how to work in small teams, having done so multiple times. This is an area I would especially like to expand my abilities in.

While I'm not particularly artistically inclined, I know how to create, edit and optimize 2D graphics, both raster and vector. I am competent at using Figma to create web designs and have the fundamental skills for realizing such designs.

I'm comfortable with using Linux, in fact I prefer to. I know how to handle virtual machines, how to set up computer networks and web servers and how to troubleshoot IT problems. I'm also familiar with computer hardware.

This is the website you're on right now! The desktop view is inspired by the fact that a lot of websites ignore the horizontal offered by modern monitors and a desire to integrate navigation with the content of the site. The site is written with React.js and Tailwind. And uses Next.js to build the site for deployment on GitHub Pages via Actions. The actual content of the site is read from a JSON file and handled by a React Context component. The original design was created in Figma.
You can see the source code on GitHub here.
Figma LoFi prototype is here.

This is a site I made to train my vanilla JavaScript skills. The github version includes a Node.js backend for practising writing API endpoints, trying those endpoints to a MariaDB database and making API calls. The JavaScript frontend itself features modular code and object oriented programming.
The GitHub repository is here.
The frontend is live here.

content.header2: Figma design for a calendar app

content.paragraph: The purpose of this hypothetical mobile application is to enable people with mental disabilities to follow and learn how to use a calendar. So the aim of the design is to be simple, clear and easy to use rather than be eye catching or visually appealing for a wide audience.
The Figma project can be viewed here.

content.alt: Screenshot of the Arcade site showing that you can navigate with the arrow keys

content.paragraph: I made this site for collecting all my future web games in one place. Currently it features only a basic MineSweeper game, but I hope to expand it in the future when I get the free time to do so. It’s built using HTML5 with vanilla JavaScript.
You can visit the arcade here.

Currently I'm working on two team projects for clients. One is a WordPress site for a band and the other is a React app for a care home for disabled people that will help the caretakers manage the information and activity of their clients. These projects don’t just show my technical skills, but also my abilities at project management and teamwork. I hope to add concrete examples of my work here soon.
